sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• AIDS - Loss of appetite: initial, 2.5 mg ORALLY twice daily, before lunch and dinner; may reduce to 2.5 mg/day, given ORALLY in the evening or at bedtime if usual dose is intolerable; adjust to optimal clinical response, MAX 20 mg/day
  • Chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting; Prophylaxis: 5 mg/m(2) ORALLY 1 to 3 hr before chemotherapy, 5 mg/m(2) ORALLY every 2 to 4 hr after chemotherapy for a total of 4 to 6 doses/day; may increase dose by 2.5 mg/m(2) increments to MAX dose of 15 mg/m(2)/dose

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: Chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting; Prophylaxis: 5 mg/m(2) ORALLY 1 to 3 hr before chemotherapy, 5 mg/m(2) ORALLY every 2 to 4 hr after chemotherapy for a total of 4 to 6 doses/day; may increase dose by 2.5 mg/m(2) increments to MAX dose of 15 mg/m(2)/dose

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono: elderly: start at the low end of the dosing range

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • AIDS - Loss of appetite
  • Chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting; Prophylaxis
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
Postoperative nausea and vomiting; Treatment and Prophylaxis

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: hypersensitivity to dronabinol, cannabinoid, sesame oil, or any other components of this product

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• alcohol abuse or dependence; risk of dronabinol abuse/physical dependence
  • cardiac disorders; hypotension, hypertension, syncope, or tachycardia may occur
  • elderly; may be more sensitive to adverse effects
  • hazardous activities, such as operating machinery or driving; may impair cognitive and motor performance
  • psychiatric illness (mania, depression, or schizophrenia); may exacerbate
  • seizure disorder, history; may lower the seizure threshold
  • substance abuse, history; risk of dronabinol abuse/physical dependence

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Cardiovascular:Hypertension, Hypotension, Palpitations, Tachyarrhythmia, Vasodilatation
  • Dermatologic:Flushing
  • Gastrointestinal:Abdominal pain (3% to 10%), Nausea (3% to 10%), Vomiting (3% to 10%), Xerostomia (38% and 50%)
  • Neurologic:Amnesia, Ataxia, Confusion, Coordination problem, Dizziness (3% to 10%), Somnolence (3% to 10%), Vertigo
  • Psychiatric:Anxiety, Delusion of persecution, Depersonalization, Depression, Disturbance in thinking (3% to 10%), Euphoria (3% to 10%), Hallucinations

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono:
• The exact mechanism of action of dronabinol is not known. Cannabinoid receptors in neural tissues may mediate the effects of dronabinol and other cannabinoids. Animal studies with other cannabinoids suggest that dronabinol's antiemetic effects may be due to inhibition of the vomiting control mechanism in the medulla oblongata.
  • Central sympathomimetic activity may result in tachycardia and/or conjunctival injection. Dose-related reversible effects on appetite, mood, cognition, memory, and perception also occur, subject to great interpatient variability.

sub.title: Absorption
sub.mono:
• Oral: time to peak concentration: 2 to 4h
  • Bioavailability: 10 to 20%

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Oral
store in the refrigerator or in a cool environment between 8 to 15 degrees Celsius (46 to 59 degrees Fahrenheit); do not freeze

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• psychiatric symptoms in patients with mania, depression, or schizophrenia
  • HR

11.title: How Supplied
11.mono:
• Generic
    Oral Capsule, Liquid Filled: 2.5 MG, 5 MG, 10 MG
  • Marinol
    • Oral Capsule: 2.5 MG
    • Oral Capsule, Liquid Filled: 5 MG, 10 MG

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Patient should avoid activities requiring mental alertness or coordination until drug effects are realized.
  • Instruct patient to rise slowly from a sitting/supine position to lessen dizziness.
  • This drug may cause flushing, nausea, vomiting, xerostomia, ataxia, confusion, coordination problem, dizziness, somnolence, vertigo, disturbance in thinking, or euphoria. Elderly patients may be more sensitive to adverse effects.
  • Drug may lower the seizure threshold in patients with a history of seizure disorder.
  • Patient should report persistent signs/symptoms of hypotension, palpitations, or tachyarrhythmia.
  • Drug may exacerbate psychiatric illness. Patient should report increase in signs/symptoms of mania, depression, or schizophrenia.
  • Patient should avoid drinking alcohol during drug therapy.
